facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 765 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 765 of1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 23, 1963 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 24 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated April 23, 1963, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 24 of 1963.

facts.text: Election petition filed by respondent No. 1 Harikishan Singh challenging validity of appellant Bhaiyalal's election.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of an Election petition filed by respondent No. 1, Harikishan Singh, challenging the validity of the election of the appellant, Bhaiyalal,

facts.text: Election held for reserved seat in Berasia Constituency in district of Sehore in Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: in a reserved seat in the Berasia Constituency in the district of Sehore in Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Election held in February 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The election in question was held in February, 1962 at this election

facts.text: Appellant Bhaiyalal declared duly elected on 26th February 1962 after polling highest number of votes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was declared duly elected on the 26th February, 1962 since he had polled the highest number of votes.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 was next rival to appellant in election.

anchor.surface_text: His next rival was respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Appellant filed nomination paper on 19th January 1962 before Returning Officer at Sehore declaring himself member of Chamar scheduled caste.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had filed his nomination paper on the 19th January, 1962 before the Returning Officer at Sehore and had declared that he was a member of the Chamar scheduled caste

facts.text: Returning Officer accepted appellant's declaration of being Chamar scheduled caste.

anchor.surface_text: of the State of Madhya Pradesh in relation to Sehore district. This declaration was accepted by the Returning Officer.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 contended that Dohar caste not recognised as scheduled caste for Sehore and Raisen districts.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 contended that Dohar caste was not recognised as the scheduled caste for the district of Sehore and Raisen, and so, the Returning Officer had improperly

facts.text: Appellant contended election petition not maintainable due to non-deposit of Rs. 2000 security.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the appellant urged that the election petition filed by respondent No. 1 was not maintainable inasmuch as he had not deposited the security of Rs. 2,000

facts.text: Election Tribunal found in favour of respondent No. 1 on caste issue and against appellant on security deposit issue.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal considered the oral evidence adduced by the parties, examined the documents on which they respectively relied, and found in favour of respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Election Tribunal allowed petition and declared appellant's election invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the election petition was allowed and the appellants election declared invalid.

facts.text: Appellant preferred appeal to Madhya Pradesh High Court which dismissed it on 23rd April 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision of the Election Tribunal, the appellant preferred an appeal to the Madhya Pradesh High Court. ... In consequence, the appeal preferred by the appellant was dismissed on the 23rd April, 1963.

facts.text: High Court confirmed Tribunal's findings that election petition valid and security deposited properly.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has confirmed the finding of the Election Tribunal on both the points. It has held that the election petition filed by respondent No. 1 was valid

facts.text: High Court agreed with Tribunal that appellant not Chamar by caste and not entitled to reserved seat.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits of the controversy as to whether the appellant was a Chamar by caste and as such was entitled to be elected for the reserved seat

facts.text: Appellant claimed he was Dohar Chamar, sub-caste of Chamar, also called Mochi.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellants case was that he was a Dohar Chamar which according to him is a sub-caste of the Chamar scheduled caste. He urged that the said sub-caste was also called Mochi.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 claimed Dohar caste distinct from Chamar, no intercaste marriage or dining.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 examined 13 witnesses belonging to the caste of the appellant. All of them asserted that they did not belong to the Chamar caste. ... There was no intercaste marriage nor even inter- caste dinners

facts.text: Kishanlal PW4, Secretary of Dohar Samaj started by appellant, testified Dohar different from Chamar.

anchor.surface_text: Amongst the witnesses examined by respondent No. 1, the High Court has attached considerable significance to the evidence of Kishanlal, P. W. 4., He was the Secretary of the Dohar Samaj started by the appellant himself.

facts.text: Documents Exts. P.2 to P.5 signed by appellant in 1956 describe him as Dohar, not Chamar.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his oral evidence, respondent No. 1 produced certain documents, Exts. P. 2, P. 3, P. 4 and P. 5. These are all signed by the appellant and they relate to the year 1956.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds concurrent findings of Tribunal and High Court against appellant on caste.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the question which arose between the parties for decision in the present proceedings is a question of fact and on this question both the Tribunal and the High Court have made concurrent findings against the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds no reason to interfere with concurrent findings that appellant does not belong to Chamar caste.

anchor.surface_text: we are satisfied that there is no reason to interfere with the concurrent finding recorded by the Tribunal and the High Court on the main question of fact.

facts.text: Appellant not qualified to contest reserved seat for Chamar scheduled caste.

anchor.surface_text: We must, accordingly, hold that the appellant does not belong to the Chamar caste and as such was not qualified to contest the reserved seat

facts.text: Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950 specifies Chamar, Jatav or Mochi.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the notification refers to Chamar, Jatav or Mochi, and so, in dealing with the question in dispute between the parties

facts.text: Dohar caste not listed as sub-caste of Chamar in Presidential Order under Article 341.

anchor.surface_text: the plea that though the appellant is not a Chamar as such, he can claim the same status by reason of the fact that he belongs to the Dohar caste which is a sub-caste

issues.text: Whether the appellant belonged to the Chamar scheduled caste and was qualified to contest the reserved seat in the Berasia Constituency

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of an Election petition filed by respondent No. 1, Harikishan Singh, challenging the validity of the election of the appellant, Bhaiyalal, in a reserved seat in the Berasia Constituency

issues.text: Whether the election petition filed by respondent No. 1 was maintainable inasmuch as he had deposited the security of Rs. 2,000 in the manner prescribed by the statutory rules

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the appellant urged that the election petition filed by respondent No. 1 was not maintainable inasmuch as he had not deposited the security of Rs. 2,000

issues.text: Whether the Dohar caste is a sub-caste of the Chamar scheduled caste

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the question which arose between the parties for decision in the present proceedings is a question of fact and on this question both the Tribunal and the High Court have made concurrent findings against the appellant.

issues.text: Whether an enquiry into whether a person belongs to an unlisted sub-caste of a notified Scheduled Caste is permissible under Article 341 and the Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950
Whether it was competent for the President to specify the lists of Scheduled Castes by reference to different districts or sub-areas under Article 341(1)

anchor.surface_text: We must, accordingly, hold that the appellant does not belong to the Chamar caste and as such was not qualified to contest the reserved seat

arguments.claim: Plea that Dohar is sub-caste of Chamar not entertainable; must strictly follow Presidential Order under Art 341 listing specific castes

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally, we may point out that the plea that the Dohar caste is a sub-caste of the Chamar caste cannot be entertained in the present proceedings in view of the Constitution  Scheduled Castes  Order, 1950.

arguments.claim: Enquiry limited to whether candidate is listed caste (Chamar, Jatav, Mochi); no enquiry into unlisted sub-castes
arguments.court_reasoning: Cites Basavalingappa as exception; normal rule no evidence to modify list

arguments.claim: President competent to specify Scheduled Castes by reference to different districts or sub-areas under Art 341(1)
arguments.court_reasoning: Art 341 authorises specification by parts/groups/areas based on backwardness varying by region

arguments.claim: President not competent to specify SC lists by different districts/sub-areas; must be for entire State
arguments.court_reasoning: Object is protection based on varying backwardness; authorised to limit to parts/areas

anchor.surface_text: Amongst the witnesses examined by respondent No. 1, the High Court has attached considerable significance to the evidence of Kishanlal, P. W. 4., He was the Secretary of the Dohar Samaj started by the appellant himself.

arguments.claim: Order specifies castes with synonyms/subcastes where applicable, but Dohar not included under Chamar for this area

anchor.surface_text: Whilst we are referring to this aspect of the matter, we may point out that the Order has taken good care to specify different castes under the same heading where enquiry showed that the same caste bore different names, or it had sub- castes which were entitled to be treated as scheduled castes

holdings.text: The appellant does not belong to the Chamar caste and as such was not qualified to contest the reserved seat for the scheduled caste of Chamars in the Constituency in question.

anchor.surface_text: We must, accordingly, hold that the appellant does not belong to the Chamar caste and as such was not qualified to contest the reserved seat for the scheduled caste of Chamars in the Constituency in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of Tribunal and High Court on question of fact upheld after review of oral and documentary evidence; no reason to interfere with usual practice.

holdings.text: The plea that the Dohar caste is a sub-caste of the Chamar caste cannot be entertained in the present proceedings in view of the Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally, we may point out that the plea that the Dohar caste is a sub-caste of the Chamar caste cannot be entertained in the present proceedings in view of the Constitution Scheduled Castes Order, 1950. This Order has been issued by the President under Article 341 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheduled Castes Order issued under Art. 341 fixes the list; cannot be varied except by Parliament under cl.(2).

holdings.text: In order to determine whether or not a particular caste is a scheduled caste within the meaning of Art. 341, one has to look at the public notification issued by the President in that behalf.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 341(1) empowers President to specify by notification; cl.(2) prohibits variation except by Parliament.

holdings.text: The enquiry which the Election Tribunal can hold is whether or not the appellant is a Chamar, Jatav or Mochi.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification specifies exact castes; enquiry confined to listed entries.

holdings.text: The plea that though the appellant is not a Chamar as such, he can claim the same status by reason of belonging to the Dohar caste which is a sub-caste of the Chamar caste, cannot be accepted; an enquiry of this kind would not be permissible having regard to the provisions contained in Art. 341.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Normal rule prohibits evidence to modify list; exceptional only in special circumstances as in Basavalingappa.

holdings.text: It is competent to the President to specify the lists of Scheduled Castes by reference to different districts or sub-areas of the States under Art. 341(1).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 341(1) authorizes specification limited to parts, groups or areas based on varying degrees of backwardness across regions.

holdings.text: The election petition filed by respondent No. 1 was valid and the security deposit was made in accordance with the statutory requirements.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has confirmed the finding of the Election Tribunal on both the points. It has held that the election petition filed by respondent No. 1 was valid and the security deposit was made by him in accordance with the statutory requirements.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirms concurrent findings of Tribunal and High Court without interference.

precedents.citation: B. Basavalingappa v. Munichinnappa Others, 1 1965 1 S.C.R. 316

anchor.surface_text: B. Basavalingappa v. Munichinnappa Others, 1

precedents.cited_proposition: it is not open to make any modification in the Order by producing evidence to show that though caste A alone is mentioned in the Order, caste B is also a part of caste A and therefore must be deemed to be included in caste A; normally no enquiry to equate a caste to a scheduled caste unless special circumstances
precedents.cited_holding: an enquiry into whether Voddar caste was the same as Bhovi scheduled caste was permissible due to special and unusual circumstances

anchor.surface_text: but in cases of this kind where the Tribunal and the High Court make concurrent findings on questions of fact, this Court does not usually interfere and after hearing Mr. Chatterjee we see no reason to depart from our usual practice in this matter. Respondent No. 1 examined 13 witnesses belonging to the caste of the appellant. All of them asserted that they did not belong to the Chamar caste. According to their evidence, the Dohar caste was different from the Chamar caste. There was nointercaste marriage no even inter- caste dinners between the members of the said two castes. This evidence shows that Chamars and Mochis of Sehore district lived in mohallas different from the mohallas in which the Dohars lived.

outcome.relief_summary: No interference with concurrent findings of Tribunal and High Court; appellant not belonging to Chamar caste and not qualified for reserved seat upheld

anchor.surface_text: We must, accordingly, hold that the appellant does not belong to the Chamar caste and as such was not qualified to contest the reserved seat for the scheduled caste of Chamars in the Constituency in question.

but in cases of this kind where the Tribunal and the High Court make concurrent findings on questions of fact, this Court does not usually interfere and after hearing Mr. Chatterjee we see no reason to depart from our usual practice in this matter. Respondent No. 1 examined 13 witnesses belonging to the caste of the appellant. All of them asserted that they did not belong to the Chamar caste. According to their evidence, the Dohar caste was different from the Chamar caste. There was nointercaste marriage no even inter- caste dinners between the members of the said two castes. This evidence shows that Chamars and Mochis of Sehore district lived in mohallas different from the mohallas in which the Dohars lived.

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally, we may point out that the plea that the Dohar caste is a sub-caste of the Chamar caste cannot be entertained in the present proceedings in view of the Constitution Scheduled Castes Order, 1950. This Order has been issued by the President under Article 341 of the Constitution.

but in cases of this kind where the Tribunal and the High Court make concurrent findings on questions of fact, this Court does not usually interfere and after hearing Mr. Chatterjee we see no reason to depart from our usual practice in this matter. This evidence shows that Chamars and Mochis of Sehore district lived in mohallas different from the mohallas in which the Dohars lived.
